name: Miso Cod (Black Cod with Miso)
description: Make Nobu‚Äòs famous Miso Cod at home today! Also known as Black Cod with Miso, this classic Japanese seafood dish is delicate, buttery, and melt-in-your-mouth delicious. You‚Äòll be surprised by how easy it is to pull this off at home.

video.description:
Marinated in saikyo miso and baked to perfection, Black Cod with Miso is a beautiful seafood dish you can pull off at home. With its delicate and buttery texture, the Miso Cod simply melts in your mouth.

RECIPE starts ‚ñ∂ 01:02

PRINT RECIPE ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/MisoCodRecipe

Prep Time: 10 mins
Cook Time: 20 mins
Total Time: 2 Days 30 mins
Servings: 4

INGREDIENTS

4 fillets sablefish (gindara) (you can also use salmon, sea bass, etc.)
2 tsp Kosher salt
2 Tbsp sake

- Miso Marinade -
6 Tbsp miso (saikyo miso or white miso)
3 Tbsp mirin (if you use white miso, use 2 Tbsp mirin instead 1¬Ω)
3 Tbsp sake

INSTRUCTIONS with step-by-step pics ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/MisoCodRecipe

How to Make Miso Cod (Black Cod with Miso) (Recipe) ÈäÄ„ÉÄ„É©„ÅÆË•ø‰∫¨ÁÑº„Åç„ÅÆ‰Ωú„ÇäÊñπ („É¨„Ç∑„Éî)

recipeIngredient: 4 fillets sablefish (gindara) ((4-6 oz or 113-170 g per fillet; skin-on; about 1 inch or 2.5 cm thick))
2 Tbsp sake ((to clean the fish and remove its odor))
6 Tbsp Saikyo miso (Kyoto-style white miso) ((Ë•ø‰∫¨Âë≥Âôå, a sweet white miso))
6 Tbsp white miso ((for miso types that are saltier than white miso, add more mirin or/and sugar))

recipeInstructions.text: Before You Start: Select the freshest fish possible, as you will be marinating this fish for a few days. Please note that this recipe requires a marination time of 2‚Äì3 days.¬†If you use skinless fish, marinate it for a shorter period of time. You can also use salmon and sea bass in this recipe.
recipeInstructions.name: Before You Start: Select the freshest fish possible, as you will be marinating this fish for a few days. Please note that this recipe requires a marination time of 2‚Äì3 days.¬†If you use skinless fish, marinate it for a shorter period of time. You can also use salmon and sea bass in this recipe.
To Marinate the Fish (2‚Äì3 days before serving)

itemListElement.text: Sprinkle 2 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt over 4 fillets sablefish (gindara) and set it aside for 30 minutes. The salt will draw out excess moisture and reduce the fish‚Äòs odor.
itemListElement.name: Sprinkle 2 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt over 4 fillets sablefish (gindara) and set it aside for 30 minutes. The salt will draw out excess moisture and reduce the fish‚Äòs odor.

itemListElement.text: Meanwhile, make the marinade. In a bowl, add 6 Tbsp Saikyo miso (Kyoto-style white miso), 3 Tbsp mirin, and 3 Tbsp sake for the traditional recipe. (Optional: If you are making the optional recipe using 6 Tbsp white miso, add 1 Tbsp sugar.) Tip: While in some recipes we can replace sake with water, it‚Äòs not a suitable substitute in this recipe due to the longer marination time required.
itemListElement.name: Meanwhile, make the marinade. In a bowl, add 6 Tbsp Saikyo miso (Kyoto-style white miso), 3 Tbsp mirin, and 3 Tbsp sake for the traditional recipe. (Optional: If you are making the optional recipe using 6 Tbsp white miso, add 1 Tbsp sugar.) Tip: While in some recipes we can replace sake with water, it‚Äòs not a suitable substitute in this recipe due to the longer marination time required.

itemListElement.text: Mix it all together and pour the marinade into a flat-bottomed airtight container.
itemListElement.name: Mix it all together and pour the marinade into a flat-bottomed airtight container.

itemListElement.text: Pour 2 Tbsp sake over the fish to rinse off the salt. Gently pat dry with a paper towel to remove the moisture. Do not wash the fish under running water.
itemListElement.name: Pour 2 Tbsp sake over the fish to rinse off the salt. Gently pat dry with a paper towel to remove the moisture. Do not wash the fish under running water.

itemListElement.text: Place the fish in the container and coat both sides of the fish with the marinade.
itemListElement.name: Place the fish in the container and coat both sides of the fish with the marinade.

itemListElement.text: Slather the fillets with the marinade. Cover the container and keep it in the refrigerator for up to 2‚Äì3 days for the traditional method. Tip: If you are not using Saikyo miso or regular white miso, you can reduce the marination time to several hours or overnight. Since other miso types are saltier than white miso, please adjust the flavor by adding more mirin or/and sugar.
itemListElement.name: Slather the fillets with the marinade. Cover the container and keep it in the refrigerator for up to 2‚Äì3 days for the traditional method. Tip: If you are not using Saikyo miso or regular white miso, you can reduce the marination time to several hours or overnight. Since other miso types are saltier than white miso, please adjust the flavor by adding more mirin or/and sugar.

recipeInstructions.name: To Remove the Fish from the Marinade

itemListElement.text: With your fingers, wipe the marinade off the fish completely. Do not leave any excess marinade on the fish; otherwise, it will burn easily. At this point, you can individually wrap the fish with plastic wrap and store it in a freezer bag for up to 2‚Äì3 weeks. Defrost in the refrigerator before cooking.
itemListElement.name: With your fingers, wipe the marinade off the fish completely. Do not leave any excess marinade on the fish; otherwise, it will burn easily. At this point, you can individually wrap the fish with plastic wrap and store it in a freezer bag for up to 2‚Äì3 weeks. Defrost in the refrigerator before cooking.

recipeInstructions.name: To Prepare the Fish for Cooking

itemListElement.text: Place the fish skin side up on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper/silicone mat (for baking) or aluminum foil (for broiling).
itemListElement.name: Place the fish skin side up on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper/silicone mat (for baking) or aluminum foil (for broiling).

itemListElement.text: Preheat the oven to 400¬∞F (200¬∫C) with a rack placed in the center of the oven. For a convection oven, reduce the cooking temperature by 25¬∫F (15¬∫C). Bake the fish on the parchment paper until the surface is blistered and browned a bit, about 20 minutes. You do not need to flip the fish. Please remember the cooking time varies depending on the thickness of the fish.
itemListElement.name: Preheat the oven to 400¬∞F (200¬∫C) with a rack placed in the center of the oven. For a convection oven, reduce the cooking temperature by 25¬∫F (15¬∫C). Bake the fish on the parchment paper until the surface is blistered and browned a bit, about 20 minutes. You do not need to flip the fish. Please remember the cooking time varies depending on the thickness of the fish.

itemListElement.text: Preheat the broiler* with a rack placed about 8 inches (20 cm) away from the top heating element (in the center of the oven) for 5 minutes. Tip: When broiling, you don‚Äòt control the temperature in the oven; instead, you control the distance between the broiler and the surface of the food. It‚Äòs similar to using hotter and cooler zones on your grill. *There are usually three broiler settings: Low (450¬∫F/232¬∫C), Medium (500¬∫F/260¬∫C), and High (550¬∫F/288¬∫C). I usually use the Medium (6 inches away) or High (8 inches away) setting.
itemListElement.name: Preheat the broiler* with a rack placed about 8 inches (20 cm) away from the top heating element (in the center of the oven) for 5 minutes. Tip: When broiling, you don‚Äòt control the temperature in the oven; instead, you control the distance between the broiler and the surface of the food. It‚Äòs similar to using hotter and cooler zones on your grill. *There are usually three broiler settings: Low (450¬∫F/232¬∫C), Medium (500¬∫F/260¬∫C), and High (550¬∫F/288¬∫C). I usually use the Medium (6 inches away) or High (8 inches away) setting.

itemListElement.text: Place the fish on the foil-lined baking sheet and broil on High (550¬∫F/288¬∫C) for 8‚Äì10 minutes until the surface is blistered and browned a bit. Please remember the cooking time varies depending on the thickness of the fish and the distance between the broiler and the food. You do not need to flip the fish.
itemListElement.name: Place the fish on the foil-lined baking sheet and broil on High (550¬∫F/288¬∫C) for 8‚Äì10 minutes until the surface is blistered and browned a bit. Please remember the cooking time varies depending on the thickness of the fish and the distance between the broiler and the food. You do not need to flip the fish.

itemListElement.text: Carefully remove the fish with a spatula and remove any burnt miso from the fish. Serve immediately. I serve the fish with thinly sliced red radishes and garnish it with a small green leaf from my backyard for additional color. We always eat this dish with rice.
itemListElement.name: Carefully remove the fish with a spatula and remove any burnt miso from the fish. Serve immediately. I serve the fish with thinly sliced red radishes and garnish it with a small green leaf from my backyard for additional color. We always eat this dish with rice.

itemListElement.text: You can keep the cooked leftovers in an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator for 3 days and in the freezer for up to a month.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the cooked leftovers in an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator for 3 days and in the freezer for up to a month.

review.reviewBody: I've made this multiple times and it is DELICIOUS. It's honestly my favorite fish recipe - every time sablefish is in stock at my local market, I grab some just to make this dish. Definitely worth tracking down some saikyo miso (it's available on Amazon). Sublime - highly recommend!
Have you tried this with a whole fish?  Would it work?  Love it with filets!
Hello would you please be able to suggest which sake and mirin she uses for this recipe? Looking for the specific brands/item... would love to get it as close as possible thank you soooo much!
Beyond delicious and so so easy!!
Love, love, love this recipe absolutely delicious.  Took me back to the 1st time I had miso cod in Japan.  Paired it with the chestnut rice (from JOC) and asparagus with sweet sauce.
Hello, thank you so much for this recipe, it is delicious!! I want to make it again with a whole sablefish I purchased, can I marinate it the same way and bake in the oven?
How do we know the fish is done? Is there a target temperature?

keywords: black cod, miso, miso cod, saikyoyaki
